Award.AwardTitle: Ecological and evolutionary dynamics of range limits in the scarlet monkeyflower
Award.AbstractNarration:
Although some species range widely across continents while others are found in only a handful of locations, every species on earth has a geographic distribution that is circumscribed by range boundaries. The ecological and evolutionary factors that give rise to range boundaries remain poorly understood for most species, yet they are of direct relevance for understanding potential biological responses to climate change. Range boundaries are hypothesized to be set by the combined action of spatial variation in habitat suitability, dispersal and gene flow (the movement of individuals and their genes between populations), and demography (aspects of individual performance and population growth). Depending on the relative balance of these factors, range margins may represent stable areas where species have failed to adapt to particular climatic conditions, or they may represent areas that are the forefront of range shifts under changing climatic regimes. In this study, factors that limit the geographic range of the scarlet monkeyflower (Mimulus cardinalis) in western North America will be investigated using field surveys, population modeling, and population genetic assays. The goal is to understand how spatial variation in habitat suitability, gene flow and demography give rise to stable or transient range boundaries.

An existing partnership with Yosemite National Park will be used to enhance public dissemination of results of this research. An education ranger will present information on the biological effects of climate change in national parks. A postdoctoral researcher, a female doctoral student, and a minority undergraduate will be trained as part of this project. Undergraduates will participate in a summer program at Colorado State University that enhances the undergraduate research experience through independent projects and professional development seminars.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Every species on earth has a unique spatial distribution, known as its geographic range. Species vary considerably in the characteristics of their geographic ranges, both where on Earth they are distributed and how broadly they are distributed. But, the range of every species is circumscribed by boundaries known as range limits. Many possible explanations for range limits have been proposed, from climate, to competitors, to past events in evolutionary history. Understanding the causes of range limits is critical for predicting how species’ geographic ranges may change as the Earth’s climate dramatically changes over the coming decades.

 

This project provided a comprehensive test of some of the key factors that may set geographic range limits. We focused on a perennial plant species, the scarlet monkeyflower (Mimulus cardinalis, Phrymaceae), a native wildflower of western North America. Plant species provide an excellent system to research geographic ranges and their limits because they can be easily surveyed in the field, their tissue can be safely collected for DNA analyses, and the survival and reproductive success of specific individuals can be easily quantified. Furthermore, herbarium collection records can provide an estimate of the geographic range of a species. We used three general approaches to study the causes of geographic range limits in the scarlet monkeyflower: 1) field surveys of plant presence and absence across the geographic range, 2) demographic monitoring of populations from across the geographic range, and 3) genetic analyses of numerous populations distributed throughout the range. We describe the key results from each of these approaches below.

 

Species geographic ranges may be limited by dispersal (i.e., the ability to colonize suitable habitat beyond a present range limit) or by fitness (i.e., no suitable habitat to support populations available beyond the range limit). If a range limit is created by dispersal limitation, then suitable habitat should be available beyond the range limit but species will fail to occupy it. On the other hand, if a range limit is created by fitness limitation, then habitat suitability should decline at and beyond range limits. Over the course of two summer field seasons, crews of undergraduate and post-graduate students surveyed 240 randomly selected points across the known geographic range of M. cardinalis. Crews determined if M. cardinalis individuals were present or absent (and, if present, how abundant) and measured a series of microhabitat characteristics. These data represent one of the most comprehensive surveys of a natural plant species’ populations across its entire geographic range. The presence and absence data, in conjunction with the microhabitat measurements and climatic values derived from public databases, were used to build ecological niche models (ENMs), which are statistical descriptions of the set of environmental characteristics a species requires to maintain a population. We used the ENMs to determine how habitat suitability and the occupancy of suitable habitat vary across the geographic range. We found that suitability declines from the center to the edges of the range, consistent with fitness limitation. Also, occupancy of suitable habitat was lower at the northern range edge compared to the range center, suggesting an additional role for dispersal limitation.
